document.text: requested that plans for a proposed 48-unit! apartment complex be resub mitted by Virten, Lid. toyclwify questions involving federal funding for the project. Supervisors had rejected prelimi nary plans for the project -at their - March meeting, citing problems with design of the  complex, and the possibility of using an existing su bsidized-housing plan to meet the needs of moderate incomefamilies in Appomattox. In March, the supervisors heard a report from Watkins Abbitt, Jr., who said that his housing committee did not feel the income range specified for renters of the apartments - 7,200 to 15,600 - was low and moderate in this county. Abbitt also said the preliminary design for the apartments would not accomodate elderly and handicapped pel-sons, as many of the units Would be accessible only by steps. Representatives from Bradley and Trinkle, a Roanoke-based development firm hoping to gain approval for the project, explained that tne apartments would not be rent-subsidized, and that eight of the 48 units would lui f accessible to the handicapped. Tom Trinkle, of the developers, noted that there had been an apparent misunderstanding between the Super visors and Greater Boston Develop ment, Inc., a Massachusetts firm which originally subm itted the apartment complex proposal. Abbitt said that he felt the board had been misled, and board members .requested that the plans, including spécifications for renter eligibility, be submitted again fer consideration. . In other business, board members heard a request from Mr. and Mrs. Nugene Harvey, owners and operators of the Southside Country Club on Route 460 west of the. town of Appomattox, for an amendment to an ordinance regulating nightclubs. They asked the supervisors for an amendment which would allow their and h er simil establishment to stay open until 2 a.m., rather than 1 a.m. on weekends, as stipulated in the ordinance. Mr. Harvey noted that the ely closing time was hurting his business, since many of his patrons work late and dont get off from work in time to get to the establishment before it closes. Commonwealths A ttorney Sam Kerr noted that the board could advertise proposed change in the ordinance regulating such establish ments and base their decision on public input. document.text: Liberty Baptist Church Youth Week will climax Sun day with a youth team from Washington and Lee University and Longwood College leading. Last Sunday morning at the close of the worship service Richard Smith was presented the Tell - star Emblem which symbolizes the theme for Youth Week. The Youth Week Pastor, Dicky Smith, and the associate pastor, Watkins Abbitt, Jr., and about fifty other young people lead the services this week and will bring it to a close Sunday morning at the worship hour. Ashley Wiltshire and Malcolm Morris of the Washington and Lee University and Miss Faye Stone of Longwood College will lead In a special service Friday night beginning at 630 with a fellowship supper. Activities in clude a Youith Forum, Fellow ship and Dedication s e r v i c e . Saturday night beginning at 715 all Appomattox Baptist Associa tion youth will assemble at Lib erty for an inspirational serv ice, c o n f e r e n c e and fellow ship. document.text: Representative Abbitt was elected toCongr e s s onFebr- uary 17, 1948 to fill the vacancy  caused by the death of Patrick H. Drewry who had served as Commonwealths Attorney for Appomattox County s ix t e e n years, between 1932 and 1948. As Four District Congress man, he r e p r e s e n t s sixteen counties and the cities of Chesa peake, Colonial Heights, Em poria, Franklin, Hopewell,Pet ersburg and Suffolk. Abbitt is dean of the Virginia delegation in Congress and is among the top 10 in seniority among the 435 members of the House. He is 4th ranking mem ber of the House Agriculture Committee, 4th ranking mem ber of the House Administra tion Committee and one of twel ve members of the non-partisan House Ethics Committee. He is chairman of two all important subcommittees and also serves on several other subcommit tees. Representative Abbitt has been active in the political life of Appomattox County and the State of Virginia for many years. Born May 21, 1908, he is a graduate of Appomattox High School and the University of Richmond Law School. In 1964 he was awarded an honorary Doctor of Laws Degree by the U. of Richmond. While maintaining an active interest in district, state and national affairs, he has retained his active role in his own com munity, in civic and church af fairs. He is married to the former Corinne Hancock and the Abbitts have three children, Mrs. Anne Abbitt Kerr, Watkins, Jr. and Corinne. Give I I

document.text: Appomattox County marked its 127th year in 1972 as a county always keeping in mind the happenings in past years but at the same time looking to a brighter future. The big story of the year came with the announcement that THOMASVILLE FURNI TURE INDUSTRIES, with headquarters in Thomasville, North Carolina, planned to build a major manufacturing facility in Appomattox a 350,000 square foot plant and that they had taken an option on a 100-acre tract of land on U. S. Route 460, adjacent to the western limits of the Town of Appomattox. Initial employ ment was set at 250 persons, and, after a year or two of pro duction, employment should reach 600 to 700. This announcement came in July of 1972. In August of 1972, the Vir ginia Employment Commission was requested by Thomasville Furniture Industries, Incor porated, to make a survey of people interested in employ ment in the Appomattox area. The labor survey, conducted on August 11th and August 12th, was termed a great success by th e Virginia Employment Commission when a total of 1668 persons registered show ing an interest in employment during the two-day survey. And finally, at a meeting held in the Court, House j,. Appomattox on November 14, 1972, Thomasville Furniture Industries finalized the deal on the land located on Highway 460 for the new facility to be built here. Plans will soon be let for bids and we can look forward to the beginning of the construction of the new plant The news in Appomattox County ranking second came when the county was declared a disaster area for the second time in three years when our county and surrounding count ies were hit by heavy rains from tropical storm Agnes causing heavy flood damage. Damage to Appomattox County was estimated at 995,000. One person was reported dead due to the high waters. Major damage to roads and highways in the county totaled 195,000 m i n o r damage totaled 50,000 and damage to bridges totaled 30,000. These are estimated totals. Estimated damage to personal property in Appo mattox County totaled 49,500 estimated damage to industry totaled 10,000 businesses in the county receiving damage totaled 23,000 and an estimated damage of 637,500 was done to farm buildings, equipment, crops, animals and land. Flood victims were assured of assistance. In March of 1972 Fourth District Representative Wat- kin M. Abbitt, Democrat of Appomattox, announced that he would retire from Congress at the end of his term of office. At that time Abbitt was a 24-year veteran of the Fourth District. A graduate of Appomattox High School and the University of Richmond Law School, he was awarded an honorary Doctor of Law Degree in 1964 by the University of Richmond. He was always, and still is, active in community, civic and church affairs in Appomattox County while maintaining an active interest in the Fourth District, in the State and in National affairs. Abbitt is married to the former Corinne Hancock and they have three children, Mrs. Anne Abbitt Kerr, Watkins, Jr., and Corinne. document.text: A full-time Fifth District Congressional office will be opened in Farmville as early as practicable according to Representative W. C. Daniel. Watkins M. Abbitt, Jr., has been appointed to be manager of Congressman Daniels field office in Farmville. The office will be open daily. Watkins is the son of Honor able and Mrs. Watkins M. Abbitt of Appomattox. He is a graduate of Appomattox High School and a graduate of Vir ginia Commonwealth Univer sity, Richmond. He has been interested in politics for a number of years, attending the Democratic Nat ional Convention in Miami, Florida, in July of 1972 as a delegate from the Fifth Con gressional District. Congressman Daniel has maintained a full-time district office in his home-town of Danville ever since going to Congress in 1969. October 4 in Liberty Baptist Church, of which she was one of the oldest members, with interment in Liberty cemetery. Her pastor, Dr. Carl A. Collins, Jr., conducted the services, assisted by two former pas tors of her church, Dr. W. M. Thompson of Middleburg, Virginia and Dr. V. W. Sears of Clifton Forge. Honorary. pallbearers were the Deacons of her chuch and flow er bearers were members of the Womans Missionary Society. Active pallbearers were Charles T. Moses Alfred R. Harwood, Jr George F. Abbitt, Jr., Alfred Lawson, and four of her nephews, Ned LeGrand of Appomattox Luther B. LeGrand Jr., and William A. Kelley of Lynch burg, and Charles L. Mason of Crewe.

document.text: Mrs. Rosa Reynolds Buchanan died January 21 at her home here, after an illness of three months. She was born in Appomattox Coun ty June 13, 1898, daughter of Thomas Edwards and Emma Jones Reynolds. She was the wife of form er Appomattox Mayor George B. Buchanan, who also served as Ap pomattox County Treasurer, Besides her hufband, she is sur vived by three daughters, Mrs. Jo seph Tindall, Middletown, N. J. Mrs. Charles Morris, Richmond and Miss Ilah Buchanan, with the State Department in Saigon, Viet Nam one son, George B. Buchanan Jr., Appomattox one brother, Ho mer W. Reynolds, Ashbury Park, N. J., and four grandchildren. Funeral services were held at 2 P. M. Monday, at Robinsons Fu neral Home here. Interment was in Liberty Cemetery. Services were conducted by Dr. Carl A. Collins, Jr. Dr. Twyman Williams, and the Rev. Lee H. Richcreek. Active pallbearers were David T. Robertson, Grover Smith, A. R. Har wood Jr., Billy Conner, Robert C. Hubbard and William C. Hubbard. Honorary pallbearers were Dr. C. F. James, Watkins M. Abbitt, George Abbitt Jr., George Abbitt Sr., Chas. F. P. Crawley, J. A. Burke, William Burke, H. C. Pul liam, Carroll Ould, Calvin Robinson, Leonard E. Anderson, Fred Lawson, Jesse Guill, Robert Alford, Thos. T. Martin, Joel W. Flood, C. T. Moses, C. T. Moses Jr.

document.text: A meeting of Appomattox Coun-  ty voters will be held at the Court  House Monday night at 730, for i the purpose of planning for a re presentative vote in the approach ing November 8 general election. A major object of the meeting will be to discuss the proposed poll tax amendment to the State Constitu tion, which will be voted on at the same time as the candidates for Governor, Lieutenant Governor and Attorney General. This meeting is being called by State Senator C. T. Moses, Watkins M. Abbitt and George Abbitt, Jr. All voters are invited.

document.text: The board of trustees of the non-partisan Americans for Constitutional Action has hon ored Fourth District Repre sentative Watkins M. Abbitt, also Senator Harry F. Byrd, Jr. and Fifth District Representa tive W. C. Dan Daniel. Representative Abbitt will recieve the ACAs Distinguish ed Service award next month. He has been a recipient in each presentation since the award was originated. The ACA presents the award every two years to those le gislators whose voting records the organization considers out standing. Senator Harry F. Byrd, Jr. was presented the ACAs Dis tinguished Service Award Wed. Dec. 15 in Washington D. C. for his support of  fundamen tal principles of good govern ment. F i f t h District Representa tive W. C. Dan Daniel also re ceived the award Dec. 15 in Washington. According to the ACA the honorees received the awards for  their outstanding record in the Congress and devotion to those fundamental principles of good government which serve to promote individual rights and responsibilities a sound dollar a growing economy and a de sire for victory over com munist aggression.

document.text: Postmaster g e n e r a l , Friday handed out the first several al bums of the Appomattox com memorative stamp. The first, he said, was to be given to President Johnson. The second album he handed to Vir ginia Governor Albertis S. Har rison. Jr., who was on the same platform with him and Cation and other notables here Friday. McMillan presented other al bums to Sen. Harry F. Byrd, Sen. A. Willis Robertson, Rep. Watkins M. Abbitt, of Appomat tox George B. Hartzog, Jr., di rector of the National Park Serv ice, John Warren Cooke chair man of the Virginia Civil War Commissions executive commit tee, Leonard Fellman who de signed the stamp, William C. Hubbard chairman of the Ap pomattox Centennial Commis sion and William Conner, Appo mattox postmaster. Dixie The audience rose en masse when the U. S. Marine band from Quantlco played Dixie. And the audience, asked to ! hold Its applause after the in troduction of all distinguished guests, clapped loudly for Rob ert E. Lee, IV. Friday night a program of Civil War music was held in the auditorium of Appomattox High School. A program in commemorative of Civil War veterans was held in the auditorium of Appomattox Elementary School at 8 p.m. on Saturday. Sunday afternoon, beginning at oclock, a peace program was held on the surrender grounds.

document.text: Mrs. Lovella McGuire and daughter, Betty Dale, and Mrs. Sallie Minchner, of Richmond, spent Sunday with their brother, G. B. Buchanan and Mrs. Bucha nan. The Buchanans took their guests on a tour of the National Park Area and then had picnic lunch at the Memorial Bridge.    Mrs. Shearer Robertson, Mrs. Ann Davis and Mr. W. H. Ro bertson returned last week from Tennessee. Mrs. Robertson and Mrs. Davis motored to Missouri and Arkansas while there.    Lt. and Mrs. G. Moses Din kins spent a few days with his parents, Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert Dinkins. Lt. Dinkins was en route from Texas to Fort Mead, Md., where he will be stationed.    Mrs. W a t k i ns Abbitt and daughters, Rinne, and Mrs. Sami Kerr, of Richmond, are spend- j ing this week at Virginia Beach.    Miss Dot Sears joined friends from Petersburg Wednesday for a trip to Nova Scotia.    Mr. and Mrs. Preston Coleman visited his sisters, Mrs. R. N. Spiggle, Mrs. Irvin C. Moses and Miss Kate Coleman Monday afternoon.    Mrs. Julian Guill and daugh-1 ter, Julia Ann, are visiting re-1 latives in Philadelphia.   m Mrs. Charlie Page visited her i sisters, Mr. Irvin C. Moses and Miss Kate Coleman on Monday, j July 20th.    Judge and Mrs. George Abbitt,  Jr. and daughter, Nancy R ep.! and Mrs. Watkins M. Abbitt and  daughter, Rinne, and Mr. and j Mrs. Ed Cawthorne attended the  annual meeting of the Common wealths Attorney association at the Cavalier Hotel in Virginia Beach over the week end.    Mrs. William B. Brown and children have returned to their home in Cincinnati after a two weeks vacation with Mr s . Browns mother, Mrs. Sue G. Johnston.    Mrs. Sue G. Johnston has re turned home after spending a week with her daughter and family, Mrs. W. A. Hickman, De catur, Illinois.    Recent guests of Mr. and Mrs. J. R. Shuford have been many of Mr. Shufords relatives of Florida. Also friends Mr. and Mrs. Carl Carter and Mr. and Mrs. Hermie Kelly also of Starke Fla.    Mr. and Mrs. Paul Bugg, Hugh and Nadine spent a recent week end visiting in Richmond.    Mr. and Mrs. R. G. Holt, Mrs. W. R. Holt, of Pamplin, Mrs. Wm C. Gaines, of Detroit, Mich., Mrs. J. R. Shuford and Mrs. Murrell Ferguson attended the funeral of Mr. Thomas Price Samuel in Petersburg Monday morning, July 20th. Mr. Samuel is Mrs. W. R. Holts brother-in- law.    Mrs. J. R. Shuford and Mrs. William C. Gaines attended the  dedication services of the new Patrick Henry Boys Cottage at Red Hill, Charlotte C o u n t y , Thursday afternoon, July 23.    Mr. and Mrs. Virgil Carson, Mr. and Mrs. Tommie Carson and family, and Mrs. Hazel Wertz, all of Roanoke, visited Mrs. David W. Smith and moth er, Mrs. J. O. Robertson, last week.    Mr. and Mrs. H. C. Thornhill, who have been making their home in Norfolk have moved to Brooklyn, N.Y. En route to New York they visited relatives in the county several days.    J. O. Robertson is recovering nicely in the Virginia Baptist Hospital where he underwent surgery.

document.text: With Virginia voters to elect a Governor, Lieutenant Governor, At torney General and members of the House of Delegates on Tuesday, Nov. 3, political interest is on the up swing here. Appeals are being made to voters by Democratic and Republi can candidates. Representative Watkins M. Ab- bitt, of Appomattox, is state chair man of the campaign for the Demo cratic nominees. George F. Abbitt Jr. is the Democratic chairman for Appomattox County, with Mrs. Cal vin Robinson co-chaifman for the ladies.

document.text: The Circuit Court of Appomattox County has ordered a psychiatric examination of Frank Mayberry, 48, accused of the slaying of two men on Feb. 25. This test will de lay trial of the accused. It is un derstood that Mayberry has been taken to Richmond for the examination by a state penitentiary psychiatrist. If he is adjudged sane by the Richmond psychiatrist, he is slated to stand trial here May 20. Mayberry was brought here from the Farmville jail Tuesday for a grand jury hearing, as the April term of the Circuit Court opened. The grand jury returned indictments charging him with the slaying of his brother-in-law, Jack Tucker, Ever green, and of Dr. David A. Christ ian, III, popular local physician who went to the Tucker home to render medical aid. The court has agreed te  defense request for an -out-of-connty jury, It is understood that a jury from Cumberland County will be used. George Abbitt Jr. and W. M. Ab- bill represent the commonwealth in the caro, and the court named W. F. Watkins, Jr. and J. B. Wall, Jr., ot Ffcrmville, to represent May- berry.  . f preliminary hearing was held him last Friday and the case-was sent on tie the grand jury by Trial Justice C. F. P. Crawley. In another murder case, tried yesterday, Julian Jones, 58, Stone wall, was acquited by a jury of a first degree murder charge result ing from the fatal shooting of William C. Hackett, 46, of Pamplin, last Christmas Eve. The jury delib erated twenty minutes and return ed a not guilty verdict.

document.text: Preliminary hearing for Frank Mayberry, accused of fatally shoot ing his brother-in-law and a local physician Feb. 25, will begin at 10 A. M. Friday in the Trial Justice court here, it was announced yester day by George Abbitt, Jr., Appo mattox Commonwealths Attorney. J. B. Wall, Jr. and William F. Watkins, Jr., both , of Farmville, were appointed by the court to re present Mayberry. Mayberry, 48, is being held in the Farmville jail. It is reported that his attorneys do not plan to have the accused appear at the prelimi- pary hearing.. The next term of the county cir cuit court is set for April 5. A rath er full docket is anticipated for that term.
